*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified upon showing a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the original order, and where the modification is in the child’s best interests.

*Blais v. Blais*, 428 Mass. 411 (1998).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified upon showing a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the original order, and where the modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Blais v. Blais*, 428 Mass. 411 (1998).support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Blais v. Blais, 428 Mass. 411 (1998), but rather a tax/double‑jeopardy decision involving a controlled substances tax. It deals exclusively with whether a drug tax constitutes punishment for double jeopardy purposes and does not address custody, modification of custody orders, or the best interests of a child. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition about standards for modifying custody orders under Massachusetts law.
*Blais v. Blais*, 428 Mass. 411 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Revenue (commissioner), pursuant to G. L. c. 58A, § 13, from a decision of the Appellate Tax Board (board), abating a controlled substances tax (CST) assessed against Robert Mullins (taxpayer) pursuant to G. L. c. 64K.… We… now affirm."

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: A parent’s relocation constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances that may warrant modification of parenting time if the move significantly impacts the child’s welfare or stability.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The case addresses removal/relocation standards under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test, not modification of parenting time based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The discussion of ‘material and substantial change’ is limited to correcting the trial judge’s view about the mother’s remarriage as a change in circumstances for custody modification generally, and does not hold that relocation itself constitutes such a change or that it warrants modification of parenting time due to impact on the child’s welfare or stability. The proposition overreads the opinion by tying relocation per se to modification standards for parenting time, which this case does not do.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘[U]pon a complaint after a divorce… the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

*Cooper v. Keto*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 490.proposition: A parent’s relocation constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances that may warrant modification of parenting time if the move significantly impacts the child’s welfare or stability.
*Cooper v. Keto*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 490.case_name: Independence Park, Inc. v. Board of Health
*Cooper v. Keto*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 490.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts land-use and administrative law case involving subdivision plans, board of health regulations, and sewer connection requirements. It does not involve family law, parental relocation, custody, or parenting time. Because the court never addresses relocation or any modification of parenting time, it cannot provide authority for the claimed proposition about a parent’s relocation constituting a material change in circumstances.
*Cooper v. Keto*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 490.relevant_excerpt: One of the critical concerns of a municipality in approving a subdivision plan is sewage disposal, a subject vested exclusively in the board of health. ... Because of the importance of sewage disposal, and because that concern applies to almost all construction, the subject is an appropriate one for local and State regulation. If the board may ignore its sewage disposal regulations in its recommendations under G. L. c. 41, § 81U, the protection afforded by G. L. c. 111, § 127P, to developers of subdivisions against changes in the State environmental code or against changes in regulations of local boards of health becomes meaningless.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in determining custody modifications, including protecting the child’s physical and emotional well-being, continuity of education, and stable routines.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that the controlling standard in custody and removal questions is the best interests of the child, and explains that this includes evaluating effects on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs and overall quality of life. While the case’s focus is relocation rather than a generic ‘modification’ context, the court clearly frames custody and removal determinations around protecting the child’s well-being and life circumstances, which fits the proposition’s substance about paramount consideration of the child’s best interests and continuity of life situation.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in determining custody modifications, including protecting the child’s physical and emotional well-being, continuity of education, and stable routines.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the touchstone inquiry is what is best for the child and then applies that standard to a custody allocation, focusing on the child’s emotional attachment, harm from disrupted relationships, stability of living arrangements, and the parents’ work schedules and ability to support both parental relationships. The court cites and applies G.L. c. 208, § 31 and prior cases to emphasize that the child’s best interests, including physical, mental, emotional health, sibling relationships, and stable care arrangements, are the paramount consideration in determining physical custody. This aligns closely with the claimed proposition about best interests and protecting the child’s well-being, continuity, and stable routines.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”}

*Ventrice v. Ventrice*, 87 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Excessive travel time on school nights has been recognized by Massachusetts courts as detrimental to a child’s well-being and contrary to their best interests.
*Ventrice v. Ventrice*, 87 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Ventrice v. Ventrice does not discuss travel time, school nights, or transportation burdens on children at all. Its custody analysis focuses on issues such as parental fitness, home conditions, medical care, and compliance with court orders, and there is no mention that excessive travel time is detrimental to a child’s well-being or contrary to their best interests. Thus, this case cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
*Ventrice v. Ventrice*, 87 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: In reviewing the order, we cannot ascertain why the judge chose not to follow the recommendations of the GAL, who reported that Michael is “the stable parent” and is “more easily accessible and [the] more cooperative” parent with whom to work. It is not obvious from the divorce judgment nisi or the accompanying memorandum that the judge considered this evidence in the record or even found that it was credible.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In cases involving relocation and custody, courts aim to minimize disruption to the child while ensuring consistency in school attendance and extracurricular activities.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is about standards for modifying custody and allowing relocation, emphasizing the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ and the child’s relationship with both parents and extended family. While it briefly notes school and activities (e.g., avoiding interruption of schooling), the court does not articulate any general principle that courts aim to minimize disruption to the child or ensure consistency in school attendance and extracurriculars as a guiding standard. Those considerations are incidental, not framed as a central doctrinal aim, so the case does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge found, ‘[b]ecause Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro . . . most of his activities take place there.’ … The first was that, since the entry of the August 25 order, ‘the joint legal and physical custody arrangement has been carried out successfully by each parent,’ and the judge announced herself satisfied with Caleb’s adjustment to it. Caleb was found to be doing well in school, where he had made friends and excelled academically. However, there are no findings, and no evidence suggesting, that Caleb would not continue to do well emotionally, physically, and developmentally if the removal were allowed.”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Where the pre-existing order is no longer feasible or practical due to a parent’s relocation, courts may adjust the parenting schedule to reduce the burden on the child.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case deals with relocation in the context of joint physical custody and the standard for allowing removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30. While it mentions that relocation constitutes a substantial change in circumstances and that courts should modify parenting plans in the child’s best interests when relocation renders the existing plan impractical, the opinion itself does not specifically frame or endorse an adjustment of the parenting schedule to ‘reduce the burden on the child’ as a distinct principle. The holding here is that removal was not in the children’s best interests and shared physical custody should continue, not that the schedule should be modified due to impracticability from relocation.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) … state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising … (4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances … renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”
